Arts Reviews

Review: The Maids

Hedgepig Theatre Company give an excitingly troublesome production of The Maids. Lily Luty reviews

Review: Faust

Swansea City Opera provide a Gothic although somewhat dated performance of Faust at the Harrogate Theatre. Daniel Bowen reviews.

Review: POSH

Jasmin Hayward reviews Dramasoc's performance of the riotous POSH.

Review: GREEK

Lined with shadows, trash and plenty of bad language, Dramsoc's version of GREEK is an intense and provocative performance. Matthew Edwards reviews

Review: Birmingham Royal Ballet presents...

Birmingham Royal Ballet delight as they present an exciting trio of Les Rendezvous, Kin and Elite Syncopations. Deborah Lam reviews.

Review: Anna Karenina

West Yorkshire Playhouse and Royal Exchange Theatre stage Tolstoy's epic love story, Anna Karenina, with much success. Anna Sinclair reviews.

YorkShakes 2015 Review: Richard III at the Guildhall

Changing venue to the Guildhall Council Chambers, Dramasoc once again deliver a haunting rendition of Richard III. Angelica Curzi reviews.

YorkShakes 2015 Review: The Taming of the Shrew

Subtle, stylish and subversive, this production of the Taming of the Shrew is one not to be missed. Lara Swan reviews.

YorkShakes Review 2015: Timon of Athens

One of Shakespeare's lesser known works, Ruth Bury reviews York Shakespeare Project's Timon of Athens.

YorkShakes 2015 Review: Richard III

Dramasoc provide a darkly tactical and gripping performance of Richard III. Performed on-campus in the Drama Barn, Lily Papworth reviews

YorkShakes 2015 Review: Shakespeare in his Cups

A playful and amusing look at Shakespeare's characters, Henry Thorpe and Noor Hemani review the boozy Shakespeare in his Cups

YorkShakes 2015 Review: The Comedy of Errors

Full of fun and farce, Jess Burgess reviews the Handlebards' final performance of the light-hearted Comedy of Errors.

YorkShakes 2015 Review: Romeo and Juliet

Performing Shakespeare's most tragic love story in a way unlike any other, Jess Burgess reviews the Flanagan Collective's Romeo and Juliet.

YorkShakes 2015 Review: King Lear

'A cornerstone of the York International Shakespeare Festival', Northern Broadsides present an alternative (although not wholly satisfying) take on Shakespeare's great King Lear. Matthew Ingram reviews

YorkShakes 2015 Review: The Diagnosis: Hamlet

High hopes were set for this Catalonian retelling of Shakespeare's Hamlet. Unfortunately, this puppetry performance fell short of the mark. Daniel Bowen reviews.

YorkShakes 2015 Review: H(2)O

With no two shows the same, Theatr Stretfa Otawa perform a charismatic and charming re-interpretation of Shakespeare's Hamlet. Joel Down reviews H(2)O

YorkShakes 2015 Review: Two Shakespeare Heroines

As York's International Shakespeare Festival opens, Lily Papworth reviews the very first production of the week: Two Shakespeare Heroines

Review: Orpheus Descending

Dramasoc succeed in giving a harrowing yet poignant performance of Tennessee Williams' Orpheus Descending. Lara Swan reviews.

Review: Macbeth

Casting a new light, both comically and culturally, on one of Shakespeare's best works, Daniel Bowen reviews Tara Arts' Macbeth.

Review: Vienna Festival Ballet

Despite the high expectations set by the Vienna Festival Ballet, their familiar favourites did not astound. Deborah Lam reviews

Review: Paul Merton's Impro Chums

Based upon audience suggestion, Paul Merton's Impro Chums is an utterly ridiculous improvisation show that will have you laughing from start to finish (and beyond). Lily Papworth reviews.

Review: The Effect

A sensitive and sympathetic exploration of psychological issues, The Effect hits hard. Joel Down reviews Dramasoc's moving interpretation

Review: Drums In The Night

As Brecht's early drama is brought to life in the Friargate Theatre, Daniel Bowen reviews York Settlement Players' insightful performance.

Review: Whiplash

Review: Top to Bottom (ODN)

Providing a refreshing commentary on contemporary relationships, Matthew Edwards reviews Lewis Chandler's Top to Bottom.

Preview: Whiplash

Ricky Jones gives us some insight into Dramasoc's upcoming ambitious yet exciting weekend show, Whiplash.

Review: Clandestine Sketch Show/ The Room: The Musical

York-based comedy company, Two Spoons Productions, stages two classic shows - The Clandestine Sketch Show and The Room: The Musical. Soon to be showing at Buxton Fringe and the Great Yorkshire Fringe, these shows are promised to make you laugh - one way or another. Kate Marshall reviews.

Review: Twelve Angry Men

A good old-fashioned piece of theatre that is certainly thought-provoking. Lily Papworth reviews the touring West-End production of Twelve Angry Men.

Review: King Lear

With York's first International Shakespeare Festival looming, Rachel Thompson reviews Northern Broadsides' fittingly unpolished and dark performance of King Lear.

Review: Hairspray

Amy Blumsom reviews York Stage Musicals's upbeat and highly entertaining performance of the sing-a-long favourite, Hairspray
